Name: Kulfi (Malai)
Description: A traditional Indian frozen dairy dessert, richer and denser than ice cream, flavored with cardamom and condensed milk.

Name: Kulfi (Pista)
Description: A pistachio-flavored Indian frozen dairy dessert, known for its creamy texture and nutty taste.

Name: Kulfi (Kesar)
Description: Saffron-infused traditional Indian frozen dessert, offering a distinct aromatic and creamy experience.

Name: Malai Chaap
Description: Soft cheese discs soaked in sweetened, thickened, and flavored milk, a rich Bengali sweet.

Name: Malpua
Description: Deep-fried pancakes soaked in sugar syrup, often flavored with cardamom and fennel seeds.

Name: Mishti Doi
Description: Sweetened thick yogurt, traditionally made by reducing milk and setting it in earthenware pots.

Name: Modak
Description: Sweet dumplings popular during Ganesh Chaturthi, filled with coconut and jaggery.

Name: Mohan Thaal
Description: A traditional Gujarati sweet fudge made from gram flour (besan), ghee, sugar, and dry fruits.

Name: Moong Dal Halwa
Description: A rich and indulgent dessert made from roasted moong dal (split yellow lentils), ghee, sugar, and milk.

Name: Mysore Pak
Description: A rich fudge-like sweet from Karnataka, made from gram flour, ghee, and sugar.

Name: Narikol Laru
Description: Sweet coconut ladoos (balls) from Assam, made with grated coconut, sugar or jaggery.

Name: Neyyappam
Description: A sweet fried pancake made from rice flour, jaggery, and ghee, popular in Kerala.

Name: Nolen Gur Rosogolla
Description: Soft, spongy cheese balls soaked in a delicate date palm jaggery syrup, a winter specialty.

Name: Nolen Gur Sandesh
Description: A Bengali sweet made from fresh paneer (chhena) flavored with seasonal date palm jaggery.

Name: Obbattu
Description: A sweet flatbread stuffed with a jaggery and lentil (chana dal) filling, popular in South India.

Name: Palada Payasam
Description: A rich and creamy rice flake pudding cooked in milk and sugar, a specialty from Kerala.

Name: Petha
Description: Translucent soft candy made from ash gourd (winter melon), originating from Agra.

Name: Phirni
Description: A creamy rice pudding made from ground rice, milk, sugar, and flavored with cardamom and saffron.

Name: Puran Poli
Description: A sweet flatbread stuffed with a delicious filling of cooked and sweetened chana dal (split chickpeas).

Name: Rabri
Description: A thickened, sweetened milk dessert, slow-cooked until layers of cream form, flavored with nuts and cardamom.

Name: Rajbhog
Description: Large, spongy cheese balls similar to Rasgulla, but often stuffed with nuts and saffron-flavored.

Name: Rasgulla
Description: Soft and spongy cottage cheese balls soaked in light sugar syrup, a classic Bengali sweet.

Name: Ras Kadam
Description: A Bengali sweet with a small rasgulla at its core, coated with khoya (reduced milk) and grated coconut.

Name: Rasmalai
Description: Soft paneer (cottage cheese) patties immersed in a rich, saffron-flavored thickened milk.

Name: Rava Laddu
Description: Sweet spherical desserts made from roasted semolina, sugar, ghee, and sometimes coconut and nuts.

Name: Rava Unde
Description: Similar to Rava Laddu, these are sweet balls made from roasted semolina, sugar, ghee, and coconut.

Name: Sandesh
Description: A dry Bengali sweet made from chhena (fresh paneer) and sugar, often flavored with cardamom or saffron.

Name: Semiya Payasam
Description: A creamy vermicelli pudding cooked in milk, sugar, and flavored with cardamom and dry fruits.

Name: Shrikhand
Description: A sweet dish made from strained yogurt, sugar, and flavored with saffron, cardamom, and nuts.

Name: Sihi Kadubu
Description: Sweet steamed dumplings, often filled with coconut and jaggery, similar to Modak but distinct.

Name: Suji Halwa
Description: A simple yet delicious semolina pudding, cooked with ghee, sugar, and water or milk.

Name: Suryakala
Description: A deep-fried, crisp pastry with a sweet, dry filling, shaped like a sun, popular in North India.

Name: Vermicelli Kheer
Description: A popular Indian pudding made with roasted vermicelli, milk, sugar, and cardamom, often garnished with nuts.

Name: Achappam
Description: A crispy, rose-shaped rice flour cookie, popular in Kerala, usually sweet or mildly savory.

Name: Adhirasam
Description: A traditional Tamil sweet fritter made from rice flour and jaggery, deep-fried.

Name: Akki Roti
Description: A savory flatbread made from rice flour, herbs, and vegetables, popular in Karnataka.

Name: Aloo Bonda
Description: Deep-fried potato dumplings coated in a spiced gram flour batter, a popular South Indian snack.

Name: Aloo Tikki Chhole Puri
Description: A complete street food meal with potato patties (aloo tikki), chickpea curry (chhole), and deep-fried bread (puri).

Name: Appam
Description: Lacy, bowl-shaped fermented rice pancakes with soft, fluffy centers, popular in South India.

Name: Appam & Stew
Description: A classic Kerala combination of soft, lacy appams served with a rich, coconut milk-based vegetable or meat stew.

Name: Appe
Description: Small, spherical, savory dumplings made from fermented rice and lentil batter, cooked in a special pan.

Name: Avalakki
Description: Refers to flattened rice (poha), often used to make quick and easy breakfast dishes.

Name: Avalakki Uppittu
Description: A flavorful dish made from flattened rice (poha) tempered with spices, vegetables, and peanuts.

Name: Badushah
Description: A flaky, layered Indian sweet resembling a glazed doughnut, soaked in sugar syrup.

Name: Bajji
Description: A general term for various vegetables (like onion, potato, chili) dipped in spiced gram flour batter and deep-fried.

Name: Banana Bajji
Description: Slices of unripe banana dipped in a spiced gram flour batter and deep-fried until crispy.

Name: Banana Chips
Description: Thinly sliced raw bananas, deep-fried until crisp, often lightly salted or spiced.

Name: Batata Vada
Description: Spiced mashed potato balls coated in gram flour batter and deep-fried, often served with Vada Pav.

Name: Beguni
Description: Slices of eggplant (brinjal) dipped in a spiced gram flour batter and deep-fried until golden and crispy.

Name: Bhel Puri
Description: A popular Mumbai street food made from puffed rice, vegetables, and a tangy tamarind sauce.

Name: Benne Dosa
Description: A buttery, crispy dosa from Davangere, known for its soft interior and generous use of clarified butter.

Name: Bhakri
Description: A rustic, unleavened flatbread made from coarse grains like jowar, bajra, or wheat, often eaten with vegetables or curries.

Name: Bhajji
Description: A general term for deep-fried fritters made with various vegetables coated in a spiced gram flour batter.

Name: Bhatura
Description: A fluffy, deep-fried leavened bread, typically made from maida (all-purpose flour), and often served with Chole.

Name: Bonda
Description: A general term for various South Indian fried snacks, often made with potato, lentil, or mixed vegetable fillings.

Name: Bread Pakora
Description: Slices of bread (sometimes stuffed) dipped in a spiced gram flour batter and deep-fried.

Name: Chakkuli
Description: Spiral-shaped, crispy, savory snack made from rice flour, urad dal, and spices, deep-fried.

Name: Chitti Pathiri
Description: Small, soft rice flour pancakes, traditionally layered, from the Malabar region of Kerala.

Name: Chole Bhature
Description: A popular North Indian dish consisting of spicy chickpea curry (chole) served with fluffy, deep-fried leavened bread (bhature).

Name: Chole Kulche
Description: Spicy chickpea curry (chole) served with soft, leavened flatbread (kulche), a common street food from Delhi.

Name: Chow Chow Bath
Description: A breakfast platter from Karnataka, combining savory Khara Bath and sweet Kesari Bath.

Name: Dabeli
Description: A sweet and spicy street food snack from Kutch, Gujarat, consisting of a spiced potato filling in a pav (bun) with chutneys and toppings.

Name: Dahi Bhalla
Description: Soft lentil fritters soaked in creamy yogurt and topped with chutneys and spices, served chilled.

Name: Dahi Puri
Description: Crisp small puris filled with potatoes, chickpeas, curd, and a medley of chutneys and spices.

Name: Dahi Vada
Description: Fried lentil dumplings soaked in water, then served in creamy yogurt with a sprinkle of spices.

Name: Dhokla
Description: A savory steamed cake made from fermented rice and chickpea flour batter, light and fluffy.

Name: Dosa
Description: A thin, crispy, savory pancake made from fermented rice and lentil batter, a staple South Indian breakfast.

Name: Dhuska
Description: Deep-fried, savory pancakes made from a batter of rice, chana dal, and urad dal, popular in Jharkhand.

Name: Fafda Jalebi
Description: A popular Gujarati combination of crispy, savory gram flour strips (fafda) and sweet, syrupy fried pretzels (jalebi).

Name: Golgappa
Description: Crispy hollow puris filled with spicy tangy water, mashed potatoes, and chickpeas.

Name: Goli Bajje
Description: Soft, fluffy, deep-fried fritters made from maida (all-purpose flour), curd, and spices, popular in Mangalore.

Name: Gudok
Description: A steamed dumpling or cake from Northeast India, often made with rice flour and savory fillings.

Name: Handvo
Description: A savory baked cake made from a batter of mixed lentils and rice, along with vegetables and spices, popular in Gujarat.

Name: Idli
Description: Soft, fluffy, steamed savory cakes made from fermented rice and lentil batter, a staple South Indian breakfast.

Name: Idli Sambar
Description: A classic South Indian breakfast combo of soft idlis served with a flavorful lentil and vegetable stew (sambar).

Name: Idiyappam
Description: Delicate string hoppers or rice noodles, steamed and served with curries or sweet coconut milk.

Name: Kachori
Description: A deep-fried, crispy, savory pastry, often stuffed with spiced lentil or potato filling.

Name: Kadala Curry
Description: A spicy and aromatic black chickpea curry, popular in Kerala, often served with Puttu or Appam.

Name: Khaman Dhokla
Description: A bright yellow, soft, and spongy savory steamed cake made from chickpea flour, seasoned with mustard seeds and curry leaves.

Name: Kanda Bhaji
Description: Crispy onion fritters made from sliced onions coated in a spiced gram flour batter and deep-fried.

Name: Kappa Puzhukku
Description: A traditional Kerala dish of mashed tapioca (kappa) cooked with coconut, green chilies, and spices.

Name: Kara Vadai
Description: Spicy, crispy, deep-fried fritters made from various lentils (like chana dal and urad dal), herbs, and spices.

Name: Kharana Mandakki
Description: A spicy and tangy snack made with puffed rice, roasted peanuts, fried gram, and spices, popular in Karnataka.

Name: Khara Bath
Description: A savory, spicy, and tangy semolina (rava) dish, cooked with vegetables and spices, popular in Karnataka.

Name: Khara Rotti
Description: A savory flatbread made with rice flour and various spices, commonly eaten in Karnataka.

Name: Khatta Dhokla
Description: A sour and tangy steamed cake made from a fermented rice and urad dal batter, a Gujarati specialty.

Name: Khichu
Description: A traditional Gujarati snack made from rice flour dough, steamed and seasoned, often served with oil and pickle.

Name: Kozhukkatta
Description: A steamed dumpling from Kerala, typically made with a rice flour shell and a sweet coconut-jaggery filling.

Name: Kuzhalappam
Description: A crispy, tubular snack made from rice flour, rolled and deep-fried, popular in Kerala.

Name: Kuzhi Paniyaram
Description: Small, spherical, savory dumplings made from fermented rice and lentil batter, cooked in a special pan with indentations.

Name: Lilva Kachori
Description: Crispy fried pastry filled with spiced fresh pigeon peas (lilva), a winter specialty from Gujarat.

Name: Litthi Chokha
Description: Roasted wheat balls stuffed with sattu (roasted gram flour) and spices, served with a smoky mashed vegetable relish (chokha).

Name: Maddur Vada
Description: Crispy, savory fritters made from a mix of semolina, rice flour, maida, onion, and spices, from Maddur, Karnataka.

Name: Mangalore Bajji
Description: Soft, fluffy, deep-fried fritters made from maida, curd, and spices, also known as Goli Bajje.

Name: Mangalore Buns
Description: Soft, fluffy, slightly sweet puri-like bread made with ripe bananas and maida, deep-fried, a breakfast favorite in Mangalore.

Name: Masala Dosa
Description: A crispy, savory rice and lentil pancake filled with a spiced potato and onion mixture.

Name: Masala Puri
Description: A spicy and tangy chaat dish with puris topped with green peas gravy, onions, and various chutneys.

Name: Medu Vada
Description: Savory, doughnut-shaped fritters made from urad dal (black gram), crispy outside and soft inside.

Name: Mirchi Bajji
Description: Whole green chilies dipped in a spiced gram flour batter and deep-fried, a spicy snack.

Name: Mirchi Pakora
Description: Spicy green chili fritters, often slit and filled with a tangy potato or spice mixture before frying.

Name: Mirchi Vada
Description: Large green chilies stuffed with a spiced potato filling, dipped in gram flour batter and deep-fried.

Name: Momo (Indian versions)
Description: Steamed or fried dumplings, commonly with vegetable or paneer fillings, served with spicy chutney.

Name: Moodé Idli
Description: Fluffy, cylindrical idlis steamed in jackfruit leaves, imparting a unique aroma and flavor.

Name: Moru Curry
Description: A light and tangy yogurt-based curry with vegetables or lentils, popular in Kerala, often served with rice.

Name: Murukku
Description: A crunchy, savory snack typically made from rice flour and urad dal flour, shaped into spirals and deep-fried.

Name: Mysore Bonda
Description: Crispy, fluffy, deep-fried fritters made from maida, rice flour, yogurt, and spices, popular in South India.

Name: Neer Dosa
Description: A thin, delicate, and soft crepe-like dosa made from a simple rice flour batter, popular in Karnataka.

Name: Neypathiri
Description: Crispy fried flatbreads made from rice flour, popular in the Malabar region of Kerala.

Name: Nippattu
Description: Crispy, savory fried crackers made from rice flour, maida, and various spices, popular in Karnataka.

Name: Nool Puttu
Description: Steamed rice flour string hoppers, typically served with stew or sweet coconut milk.

Name: Pani Puri
Description: Crispy hollow puris filled with spicy tangy water, mashed potatoes, and chickpeas, a quintessential street food.

Name: Paniyarams
Description: Small, spherical, savory or sweet dumplings made from fermented rice and lentil batter, cooked in a special pan.

Name: Patra
Description: Colocasia leaves rolled with a spiced gram flour paste, steamed, sliced, and tempered.

Name: Pav Bhaji
Description: A popular Mumbai street food consisting of a spicy mixed vegetable mash served with buttered, toasted bread rolls (pav).

Name: Pazham Pori
Description: Sweet fritters made from ripe plantains dipped in a flour batter and deep-fried, a popular snack in Kerala.

Name: Pesarattu
Description: A savory green gram (moong dal) pancake, originating from Andhra Pradesh, often served with ginger chutney.

Name: Poha
Description: A light and healthy breakfast dish made from flattened rice, tempered with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and turmeric.

Name: Poha Upma
Description: A variation of upma made with flattened rice (poha), vegetables, and tempered with spices.

Name: Puri
Description: A deep-fried, unleavened Indian bread, puffed and golden, commonly served with curries or sweets.

Name: Puttu
Description: Cylindrical steamed rice cakes, layered with grated coconut, a staple breakfast in Kerala.

Name: Pyaz Pakora
Description: Crispy, deep-fried fritters made with thinly sliced onions mixed in a spiced gram flour batter.

Name: Ragda Pattice
Description: A popular street food dish with potato patties (pattice) served with a spicy white pea curry (ragda) and chutneys.

Name: Ragda Puri
Description: Crispy puris served with a spicy white pea curry (ragda), chutneys, and finely chopped onions.

Name: Ragi Dosa
Description: A healthy and nutritious dosa made from finger millet (ragi) flour, often with added vegetables.

Name: Ram Ladoo
Description: Soft, deep-fried fritters made from moong dal and chana dal batter, topped with grated radish and green chutney.

Name: Rava Dhokla
Description: A quick and easy steamed savory cake made from semolina (rava), yogurt, and spices.

Name: Rava Idli
Description: Instant idlis made from semolina (rava), yogurt, and a tempering of spices, light and spongy.

Name: Roti
Description: A simple, unleavened flatbread made from whole wheat flour, cooked on a griddle, a staple across India.

Name: Samosa
Description: A popular crispy fried pastry filled with spiced potatoes, peas, and sometimes other vegetables or meat.

Name: Sanna
Description: A fluffy, steamed, savory rice cake, typically larger than an idli and often fermented with toddy or yeast, popular in Goan and Mangalorean cuisine.
Vegan (Yes/No): Yes (if yeast is used instead of toddy or dairy/egg)

Name: Sev Puri
Description: A popular Indian street food snack made with flat crispy puris, topped with diced potatoes, onions, various chutneys (tamarind, mint), and a generous amount of crunchy sev.

Name: ShankarPali
Description: A traditional Indian snack, typically diamond-shaped and deep-fried, which can be prepared in sweet (sugar-coated) or savory (spiced) variations.

Name: Sugiyan
Description: A sweet South Indian snack where a filling of cooked moong dal and jaggery is coated in a maida batter and deep-fried until golden.

Name: Thalipeeth
Description: A multi-grain savory pancake popular in Maharashtra, made from a special flour mix (bhajani) often including rice, wheat, jowar, bajra, and various pulses, spiced with onions and herbs.

Name: Thatte Idli
Description: A large, flat, soft idli popular in Karnataka, known for its distinct shape (thatte means plate) and often served with chutney and sambar.

Name: Thepla
Description: A soft, spiced, and lightly fried flatbread from Gujarat, typically made with whole wheat flour, fenugreek leaves (methi), and various spices. Great for travel.
Vegan (Yes/No): Yes (if oil is used instead of ghee)
Dairy-free (Yes/No): Yes (if oil is used instead of ghee)

Name: Uppittu
Description: A popular South Indian breakfast dish made from roasted semolina (rava) cooked with vegetables, spices, and tempered with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and sometimes peanuts.

Name: Uppu Manga
Description: A traditional Kerala style salted raw mango pickle, often fermented, offering a tangy and salty flavor profile, used as a condiment.

Name: Uttapam
Description: A thick, savory pancake from South India, made from fermented rice and lentil batter, often topped with finely chopped vegetables like onions, tomatoes, and chilies.

Name: Vada Pav
Description: Mumbai's iconic street food, consisting of a deep-fried potato fritter (vada) spiced with garlic and chilies, served in a soft bread bun (pav) with various chutneys.

Name: Vattayappam
Description: A soft, fluffy, and sweet steamed rice cake from Kerala, made from fermented rice batter and coconut milk, often flavored with cardamom.

Name: Vellayappam
Description: A soft, white, and slightly sweet steamed rice pancake from Kerala, similar to appam but without the crispy edges, often served with curries.

Name: Vermicelli Uppittu
Description: A quick and easy breakfast dish made from roasted vermicelli (thin noodles) cooked with vegetables, spices, and tempered with mustard seeds and curry leaves.

Name: Kanam Dhokla
Description: A type of Gujarati dhokla made from a fermented batter of various lentils (usually chana dal and urad dal) and rice, steamed to a soft, spongy texture.
Gluten-free (Yes/No): Yes (if no rice flour with gluten)

Name: Locho
Description: A popular Gujarati snack from Surat, made from a fermented batter of gram flour (besan) and spices, steamed to a soft, crumbly texture, often served with chutneys.

Name: Doodhi Muthia
Description: A traditional Gujarati snack made from grated bottle gourd (doodhi), wheat flour, chickpea flour, and spices, shaped into dumplings and then steamed or fried.

Name: Methi Thepla
Description: A variation of Thepla, specifically highlighting the use of fresh fenugreek (methi) leaves, which impart a distinct bitter-savory flavor, along with spices.
Vegan (Yes/No): Yes (if oil is used instead of ghee)
Dairy-free (Yes/No): Yes (if oil is used instead of ghee)

Name: Pyaaz Kachori
Description: A crispy, deep-fried pastry from Rajasthan, filled with a spicy and tangy mixture of sautéed onions and various spices.

Name: Appam with Egg Roast
Description: Soft, lacy, bowl-shaped rice pancakes (appam) served with a rich and spicy Kerala-style egg roast curry, where boiled eggs are cooked in a thick, flavorful gravy.

Name: Idiyappam with Coconut Milk
Description: Delicate string hoppers (idiyappam) made from rice flour, steamed and served with a rich, slightly sweet coconut milk gravy, sometimes spiced.

Name: Kappa Biryani
Description: A unique and flavorful Malabar dish from Kerala, combining cooked and spiced tapioca (kappa) with tender beef or mutton, often slow-cooked together.

Name: Pesarattu with Upma
Description: A popular Andhra Pradesh breakfast combo featuring thin, savory green gram crepes (pesarattu) served with a side of hot, spiced semolina porridge (upma).

Name: Pani Puri
Description: A popular Indian street food consisting of hollow, crispy fried puris filled with a mixture of spiced mashed potatoes or chickpeas, and served with flavorful tangy, spicy water (pani).

Name: Golgappe
Description: A popular variant of Pani Puri, often used interchangeably, focusing on the crispy hollow puri filled with spiced potatoes/chickpeas and different flavored waters (hing, pudina, imli).

Name: Bhel Puri
Description: A crunchy and flavorful Indian street food made from puffed rice (bhel), mixed with vegetables like onions and potatoes, various chutneys, and a topping of sev.

Name: Dahi Bhalla
Description: Soft lentil fritters (bhalla) soaked in creamy yogurt (dahi), topped with sweet and spicy chutneys, and garnished with spices like cumin powder and chili powder.

Name: Aloo Tikki Chaat
Description: Crispy pan-fried potato patties (aloo tikki) topped with spicy chickpea curry (ragda), various chutneys, yogurt, and garnished with onions and sev.

Name: Pakoras
Description: A variety of Indian fritters made by deep-frying vegetables (like onion, potato, spinach) or paneer coated in a spiced chickpea flour (besan) batter.

Name: Bhajiyas
Description: Similar to pakoras, these are deep-fried fritters often made with thinly sliced onions, potatoes, or other vegetables mixed with spiced gram flour batter.

Name: Kanda Bhaji Pav
Description: Crispy onion fritters (kanda bhaji) served inside a soft bread bun (pav), often with a sprinkle of dry garlic chutney, a popular street snack.

Name: Kathi Rolls
Description: A popular Calcutta street food consisting of a paratha (flatbread) wrapped around a flavorful filling, which can be vegetarian (paneer, mixed veg) or non-vegetarian (chicken, egg, mutton), often with onions and chutneys.
Vegan (Yes/No): No (contains refined flour, can contain dairy/egg/meat)

Name: Frankie
Description: Similar to a Kathi Roll, a popular Bombay street food wrap made with a thin flatbread filled with a dry vegetable or meat curry, often with raw onions and a tangy sauce.
Vegan (Yes/No): No (contains refined flour, can contain dairy/egg/meat)

Name: Puri Bhaji
Description: A classic Indian breakfast or meal featuring fluffy, deep-fried whole wheat bread (puri) served with a dry potato curry (bhaji) spiced with mustard seeds and curry leaves.

Name: Bedmi Puri
Description: A special fried Indian bread from North India, typically made with urad dal paste mixed into the flour, giving it a distinct flavor and slightly denser texture, often served with aloo sabzi.

Name: Poori Aloo
Description: Another name for Puri Bhaji, this classic combo features deep-fried puffed bread (poori) served with a flavorful potato curry (aloo).

Name: Idli Sambar and Chutney
Description: Soft, steamed rice and lentil cakes (idli) served with a savory, tangy lentil-vegetable stew (sambar) and fresh coconut or peanut chutney.

Name: Vada Sambar
Description: Crispy, savory lentil fritters (vada) made from urad dal, deep-fried and often soaked in or served with hot, tangy lentil-vegetable stew (sambar).

Name: Pongal (Ven Pongal)
Description: A savory South Indian breakfast dish made from rice and moong dal, cooked together and tempered with ghee, black pepper, cumin, and curry leaves.

Name: Pongal (Sakkarai Pongal)
Description: A sweet South Indian dish made from rice and moong dal, cooked with jaggery, ghee, cashews, and cardamom, often prepared during festivals.

Name: Idiyappam (String Hoppers)
Description: Delicate, lace-like steamed rice flour noodles or string hoppers, typically served with various curries or coconut milk.

Name: Dosa (Wheat Dosa)
Description: A quick and easy variation of the traditional dosa, made from a batter of whole wheat flour, often spiced and cooked until crispy.

Name: Luchi and Chholar Dal
Description: A traditional Bengali breakfast/meal. Luchi are fluffy, deep-fried refined flour bread, served with Chholar Dal, a sweet and savory Bengal gram lentil curry.

Name: Puri Torkari
Description: A classic combo from Bengal, featuring fluffy deep-fried whole wheat bread (puri) served with a mixed vegetable curry (torkari).

Name: Ghoogni
Description: A popular Bengali street food and snack, a savory curry made from dried yellow peas (matar), spiced with various masalas, and often topped with chopped onions and chilies.

Name: Koraishutir Kochuri
Description: A quintessential Bengali winter delicacy, these are deep-fried flatbreads (kochuri) stuffed with a mildly spiced green pea (koraishuti) filling.

Name: Thepla with Chunda
Description: Soft, spiced Gujarati flatbread (thepla) served with Chunda, a sweet and sour grated mango pickle, a popular and convenient meal.
Vegan (Yes/No): Yes (if oil is used for thepla)
Dairy-free (Yes/No): Yes (if oil is used for thepla)

Name: Pav Bhaji Dosa
Description: A creative fusion dish where the dosa (South Indian crepe) is spread with a spiced, mashed vegetable curry (pav bhaji) and sometimes topped with cheese, combining two popular street foods.

Name: Cheese Burst Dosa
Description: A popular South Indian crepe (dosa) with a generous amount of cheese melted inside, creating a 'burst' effect, appealing to cheese lovers.

Name: Schezwan Dosa
Description: A spicy Indo-Chinese fusion dosa where the crepe is spread with fiery Schezwan sauce and often filled with stir-fried vegetables or noodles.
Gluten-free (Yes/No): Yes (if no soy sauce in Schezwan)

Name: Golgappe with Hing water
Description: Crispy hollow puris filled with spiced potato/chickpeas, served with a tangy and aromatic water flavored primarily with asafoetida (hing).

Name: Golgappe with Pudina water
Description: Crispy hollow puris filled with spiced potato/chickpeas, served with a refreshing, spicy, and tangy water flavored predominantly with fresh mint (pudina).

Name: Golgappe with Imli water
Description: Crispy hollow puris filled with spiced potato/chickpeas, served with a distinctively sweet and sour water flavored with tamarind (imli).

Name: Kachori Chaat
Description: A crushed, flaky deep-fried kachori (pastry with a savory filling) topped with various chutneys, yogurt, chickpeas, and spices, creating a delightful blend of textures and flavors.

Name: Ragda Pattice
Description: A popular Mumbai street food consisting of soft potato patties (pattice) served with a spicy, flavorful white pea curry (ragda) and garnished with chutneys and onions.

Name: Mirchi Ke Pakore
Description: Large green chilies (mirchi) stuffed with a spiced potato or paneer mixture, dipped in a gram flour batter, and deep-fried until crispy. A spicy treat!

Name: Paneer Pakora
Description: Soft cubes of paneer (Indian cottage cheese) coated in a spiced chickpea flour (besan) batter and deep-fried until golden and crispy.

Name: Vegetable Chop
Description: A popular Bengali snack, these are deep-fried cutlets made from a mashed vegetable mixture (often beetroot, potato, carrots, and peas) spiced and sometimes coated in breadcrumbs.

Name: Fish Fry (Street Style)
Description: Marinated fish pieces (often surmai or pomfret) coated in a spiced batter or flour and deep-fried until crispy and golden. A common street food in coastal areas.

Name: Chicken Lollipop
Description: Popular Indo-Chinese appetizer made from frenched chicken drumettes, marinated in a spicy batter, and deep-fried or baked until crispy.

Name: Babycorn Manchurian
Description: Crispy fried baby corn tossed in a spicy, tangy, and sweet Indo-Chinese Manchurian sauce with bell peppers and onions.

Name: Veg Momos (Fried)
Description: Popular Tibetan/Nepali dumplings filled with a spiced mixture of minced vegetables, deep-fried until golden and crispy, usually served with a spicy dipping sauce.

Name: Veg Momos (Steamed)
Description: Popular Tibetan/Nepali dumplings filled with a spiced mixture of minced vegetables, steamed until soft and tender, usually served with a spicy dipping sauce.

Name: Aloo Baingan
Description: A comforting North Indian dry or semi-gravy curry made with potatoes (aloo) and eggplants (baingan) cooked together with aromatic spices.

Name: Aloo Gobi
Description: A classic North Indian dry or semi-gravy dish with potatoes (aloo) and cauliflower (gobi) sautéed with onions, tomatoes, and a blend of spices.

Name: Aloo Mutter
Description: A popular North Indian semi-dry or gravy curry combining potatoes (aloo) and green peas (mutter) in a tomato-based sauce with various spices.

Name: Aloo Posto
Description: A simple yet flavorful Bengali dry curry made with diced potatoes (aloo) and poppy seeds (posto) paste, minimal spices, showcasing the nutty flavor of poppy seeds.

Name: Avial
Description: A traditional Kerala mixed vegetable curry made with various vegetables cooked in a coconut and yogurt gravy, tempered with curry leaves and coconut oil.

Name: Baingan Bharta
Description: A popular North Indian dish made from roasted eggplant (baingan) mashed and cooked with sautéed onions, tomatoes, green chilies, and aromatic spices.

Name: Bharwan Baingan
Description: Small eggplants (baingan) slit and stuffed with a flavorful mixture of spices, often including ground peanuts or coconut, and then cooked in a rich gravy.

Name: Bharwan Bhindi
Description: Okra (bhindi) pods slit and filled with a tangy and spicy mixture of dry spices, then pan-fried or cooked to a tender crisp texture.

Name: Bhindi Masala
Description: A flavorful and versatile North Indian dish where okra (bhindi) is sautéed with onions, tomatoes, and a blend of aromatic spices until tender-crisp.

Name: Bisi Bele Bhaat
Description: A hearty and flavorful traditional Karnataka dish, a hot lentil and rice preparation cooked with mixed vegetables, tamarind, and a special spice powder.

Name: Cabbage Kofta
Description: Flavorful deep-fried or pan-fried dumplings (kofta) made from grated cabbage and spices, served in a rich, creamy, and spiced gravy.

Name: Dal Bafla
Description: A traditional Rajasthani dish, similar to Dal Bati, where wheat dough balls (bafla) are par-boiled and then baked, served with rich lentil curry (dal) and churma.

Name: Dal Bati Churma
Description: The quintessential Rajasthani thali: hard, unleavened wheat balls (bati) baked in a traditional oven, served with a spiced lentil curry (dal) and a sweet crumbly mixture (churma).

Name: Dal Dhokli
Description: A comforting Gujarati one-pot meal where spiced wheat flour dumplings (dhokli) are cooked directly in a tangy and sweet lentil (dal) stew, typically toor dal.

Name: Dal Fry
Description: A staple Indian lentil dish made by boiling various lentils (often toor dal) and then tempering them with ghee or oil, onions, tomatoes, ginger, garlic, and spices.

Name: Dal Makhani
Description: A rich, creamy, and buttery North Indian lentil dish made with whole black lentils (urad dal) and kidney beans (rajma), slow-cooked and finished with cream and butter.

Name: Dal Tadka
Description: A popular Indian lentil dish where cooked yellow lentils (toor dal or moong dal) are finished with a tempering (tadka) of ghee/oil, mustard seeds, cumin, dried chilies, and curry leaves.

Name: Dubki Wale Aloo
Description: A delicious and spicy potato curry from Uttarakhand, where small potatoes are cooked in a thin, tangy, and flavorful gravy without onion or garlic.

Name: Dum Aloo
Description: A rich and flavorful Kashmiri or Punjabi curry where small, whole potatoes are deep-fried or pan-fried and then simmered in a creamy, spiced tomato and yogurt-based gravy.

Name: Gatte Ki Sabzi
Description: A unique Rajasthani dish where steamed or fried gram flour (besan) dumplings (gatte) are cooked in a tangy yogurt-based gravy with various spices.

Name: Gujarati Dal
Description: A distinctive sweet, sour, and spicy lentil curry from Gujarat, typically made with toor dal, jaggery, tamarind, and a unique blend of spices, often tempered with peanuts and curry leaves.

Name: Kadhi Pakora
Description: A savory, tangy, and spiced yogurt-based curry (kadhi) with gram flour fritters (pakora) immersed in it, often served with rice.

Name: Karela Sabzi
Description: A traditional Indian dry curry made from bitter gourd (karela) often sautéed with onions, tomatoes, and spices, sometimes sweetened to balance the bitterness.

Name: Kashmiri Dum Aloo
Description: A signature dish from Kashmiri cuisine, small potatoes are deep-fried and then slow-cooked in a rich, spicy, and aromatic red gravy, often without onion or garlic.

Name: Ker Sangri
Description: A traditional and rustic Rajasthani dry curry made from dried wild berries (ker) and desert beans (sangri), cooked with various spices and often oil.

Name: Kofta Curry
Description: A rich and flavorful curry featuring deep-fried or pan-fried vegetable or paneer dumplings (kofta) simmered in a creamy, spiced tomato or cashew-based gravy.

Name: Lauki Kofta
Description: A delicious curry made with dumplings (kofta) prepared from grated bottle gourd (lauki) and gram flour, deep-fried and then cooked in a tomato-onion based gravy.

Name: Malai Kofta
Description: A popular North Indian rich and creamy curry, featuring soft, melt-in-your-mouth dumplings (kofta) made from paneer and potatoes, simmered in a luscious tomato-cream gravy.

Name: Mix Veg Masala
Description: A flavorful and vibrant North Indian curry made with a medley of fresh seasonal vegetables cooked in a spiced onion-tomato gravy.

Name: Mushroom Butter Masala
Description: A rich and creamy North Indian curry with mushrooms cooked in a smooth tomato-based gravy, enriched with butter and cream, similar to Butter Chicken but vegetarian.

Name: Mushroom Handi
Description: A traditional North Indian dish where mushrooms are cooked in a thick, rich, and aromatic gravy, often prepared in a 'handi' (earthen pot) for distinct flavor.

Name: Mushroom Kadai
Description: A robust North Indian dish where mushrooms are cooked with bell peppers, onions, and coarse spices in a kadai (wok), giving it a distinct earthy and spicy flavor.

Name: Mushroom Kolhapuri
Description: A fiery and intensely spiced mushroom curry from Kolhapur, Maharashtra, known for its strong flavors derived from a special Kolhapuri masala.

Name: Mushroom Masala
Description: A general term for a versatile North Indian style curry with mushrooms cooked in a rich, spiced onion-tomato gravy.

Name: Mushroom Tikka Masala
Description: Mushrooms marinated in spices and grilled or pan-fried (like tikka), then cooked in a creamy, spiced, and typically tomato-based masala gravy.

Name: Palak Paneer
Description: A classic North Indian dish featuring cubes of paneer (Indian cottage cheese) simmered in a creamy, vibrant green spinach (palak) gravy, subtly spiced.

Name: Paneer Butter Masala
Description: A rich, creamy, and mildly sweet North Indian curry with cubes of paneer cooked in a luscious tomato-based gravy, enriched with butter and cream.

Name: Paneer Handi
Description: A traditional North Indian dish where paneer cubes are cooked in a thick, rich, and aromatic gravy, often prepared in a 'handi' (earthen pot) for distinct flavor.

Name: Paneer Kadai
Description: A robust North Indian dish where paneer cubes are cooked with bell peppers, onions, and coarse spices in a kadai (wok), giving it a distinct earthy and spicy flavor.

Name: Paneer Kolhapuri
Description: A fiery and intensely spiced paneer curry from Kolhapur, Maharashtra, known for its strong flavors derived from a special Kolhapuri masala.

Name: Paneer Masala
Description: A general term for a versatile North Indian style curry with paneer cooked in a rich, spiced onion-tomato gravy.

Name: Paneer Mutter
Description: A classic North Indian semi-dry or gravy curry combining paneer (Indian cottage cheese) and green peas (mutter) in a tomato-based sauce with various spices.

Name: Paneer Tikka Masala
Description: Paneer cubes marinated in spices and grilled or pan-fried (like tikka), then cooked in a creamy, spiced, and typically tomato-based masala gravy.

Name: Pindi Chole
Description: A robust and dry chickpea (chole) curry from Rawalpindi, known for its dark color from tea leaves and deeply spiced flavor, often served without gravy.

Name: Rajma Chawal
Description: A beloved North Indian comfort food consisting of kidney beans (rajma) cooked in a thick, spicy, and tangy gravy, served with steamed rice (chawal).

Name: Sarson Ka Saag
Description: A traditional Punjabi winter delicacy made from mustard greens (sarson) and other leafy greens, slow-cooked to a thick consistency and richly spiced, typically served with makki di roti and a dollop of butter/ghee.

Name: Sev Tamatar Nu Shaak
Description: A quick and tangy Gujarati curry made from ripe tomatoes cooked with spices, and then topped with crispy sev (fried chickpea flour noodles) just before serving.

Name: Undhiyu
Description: A traditional Gujarati mixed vegetable casserole, typically prepared during winter, combining seasonal vegetables, fenugreek dumplings (muthias), and aromatic spices, slow-cooked in an earthen pot.

Name: Veg Hyderabadi
Description: A rich and aromatic mixed vegetable curry inspired by Hyderabadi cuisine, featuring a blend of vegetables cooked in a creamy, spicy gravy with distinctive whole spices.

Name: Veg Kadai
Description: A popular North Indian dish where mixed vegetables are cooked with bell peppers, onions, and coarse spices in a kadai (wok), giving it a distinct earthy and spicy flavor.

Name: Veg Kaju Masala
Description: A rich and creamy North Indian curry with mixed vegetables and whole cashews cooked in a luscious, mildly spiced gravy, often with cream or yogurt.

Name: Veg Kolhapuri
Description: A fiery and intensely spiced mixed vegetable curry from Kolhapur, Maharashtra, known for its strong flavors derived from a special Kolhapuri masala.

Name: Veg Kurma
Description: A mild, rich, and creamy South Indian or North Indian curry featuring mixed vegetables cooked in a coconut, cashew, or yogurt-based gravy.

Name: Veg Lahori
Description: A rich and flavorful mixed vegetable curry inspired by Lahori cuisine, typically featuring robust spices and a hearty gravy.

Name: Veg Navarathna Kurma
Description: A rich and indulgent Mughlai curry featuring nine (nav) different ingredients (vegetables, fruits, nuts, paneer), cooked in a creamy, mildly sweet gravy.

Name: Bharli Vangi (Stuffed Eggplant)
Description: A traditional Maharashtrian dish where small brinjals (eggplants) are stuffed with a flavorful mix of spices, coconut, and peanuts, then slow-cooked in a spicy gravy.

Name: Kadi (Rajasthani)
Description: A tangy and spicy Rajasthani Kadhi made with gram flour (besan) and sour yogurt, simmered to a thick consistency and tempered with distinct spices like dried red chilies and fenugreek seeds.

Name: Kadi (Gujarati)
Description: A quintessential Gujarati Kadhi, known for its distinct sweet and sour flavor profile, made from yogurt and gram flour, with a delicate tempering of mustard seeds and curry leaves.

Name: Bhindi Fry
Description: Simple and quick dry curry where okra (bhindi) is sliced and pan-fried with basic spices, resulting in a crispy and flavorful side dish.

Name: Pithla Bhakri
Description: A rustic Maharashtrian combo: Pithla is a spicy, thick gram flour (besan) curry, often with onions and green chilies, served with Bhakri, a flatbread made from jowar, bajra, or rice flour.

Name: Aamat
Description: A traditional Maharashtrian or Vidarbha style mixed lentil curry, typically made with various dals and vegetables, spiced with a unique regional masala.

Name: Muthiya
Description: A popular Gujarati snack made from a mixture of flour, fenugreek leaves, and spices, typically steamed and then lightly fried.

Name: Chila
Description: A savory pancake made from gram flour (besan) or a mixture of lentils, often spiced and served with chutney.

Name: Bajra Khichdi
Description: A rustic and nutritious dish made from pearl millet (bajra) and lentils, often with vegetables and spices, popular in Rajasthan.

Name: Kachri ki Sabzi
Description: A unique Rajasthani vegetable dish made from wild melons (kachri), known for its tangy and slightly bitter taste.

Name: Hara Dhania Cholia
Description: A flavorful winter dish from Haryana made with fresh green chickpeas (cholia) and coriander (dhania).

Name: Dhaam
Description: A traditional festive Himachali meal served as a thali, consisting of rice, lentils, curries, and sweet dishes.

Name: Siddu
Description: A traditional Himachali steamed bread, often stuffed with a mixture of poppy seeds, nuts, and spices, served with ghee.

Name: Babru
Description: A Himachali snack similar to a puri, made from fermented dough, often served with chana madra (chickpea curry).

Name: Kafuli
Description: A traditional Garhwali dish from Uttarakhand, made from spinach and fenugreek leaves, cooked into a thick, nutritious green curry.

Name: Garhwal ka Fannah
Description: A simple yet flavorful Garhwali dish, a split gram (chana dal) preparation, often slow-cooked to a thick consistency.

Name: Aloo Ke Gutke
Description: A simple and popular Kumaoni dish where boiled potatoes are diced and tempered with spices like turmeric, red chili, and local herbs.

Name: Dalma
Description: A unique Odia dish made with lentils and various vegetables, slow-cooked without oil and then tempered with ghee and spices.

Name: Pakhala Bhata
Description: A traditional Odia dish of cooked rice fermented overnight in water, often served with side dishes like fried fish or vegetables.

Name: Santula
Description: An Odia healthy mixed vegetable curry, lightly spiced and cooked with minimal oil, preserving the natural flavors of the vegetables.

Name: Ulli Theeyal
Description: A tangy and spicy Kerala curry made with small onions (shallots), roasted coconut, and a blend of spices.

Name: Syrian Christian Fish Curry
Description: A traditional fiery fish curry from the Syrian Christian community of Kerala, made with local fish, kokum, and a rich blend of spices.

Name: Udupi Sambar
Description: A distinctive South Indian lentil and vegetable stew, specific to Udupi cuisine, known for its unique blend of roasted spices and sweet-sour notes.

Name: Gongura Mamsam
Description: A spicy and tangy Andhra-style mutton curry made with Gongura (sorrel leaves), giving it a distinctive sour flavor.

Name: Gongura Kodi
Description: A popular and fiery Andhra-style chicken curry, prepared with Gongura (sorrel leaves) for its signature sour and spicy taste.

Name: Kandipodi
Description: A staple Andhra dry spice powder made from roasted toor dal and various spices, commonly mixed with rice and ghee.

Name: Pappula Podi
Description: Another popular Andhra dry spice powder, similar to Kandipodi, but often made with roasted gram dal and a distinct flavor profile.

Name: Palakura Pappu
Description: A nutritious Andhra dal (lentil stew) made with spinach (palakura) and pigeon peas (toor dal), mildly spiced and wholesome.

Name: Gutthi Vankaya Curry
Description: A classic Andhra dish featuring small eggplants (vankaya) stuffed with a rich, spicy, and tangy peanut-based spice paste.

Name: Bendakaya Fry
Description: A simple and delicious Andhra style stir-fry made with sliced okra (bendakaya) and basic Indian spices until crisp.

Name: Dhokar Dalna
Description: A traditional Bengali vegetarian curry made with fried lentil cakes (dhoka) cooked in a rich, spiced gravy.

Name: Mochar Ghonto
Description: A unique and flavorful Bengali dry curry made from banana blossoms (mocha) with potatoes and coconut.

Name: Muri Ghonto
Description: A traditional Bengali delicacy made with fish head, rice, and potatoes, slow-cooked to a rich and flavorful consistency.

Name: Alfaham Chicken
Description: A popular Arabian-style grilled chicken, marinated in a blend of spices and yogurt, slow-cooked on charcoal to perfection.

Name: Amritsari Machhi
Description: A famous Punjabi fried fish dish from Amritsar, marinated in a spicy chickpea flour batter and deep-fried until crispy.

Name: Ambot Tik
Description: A fiery, sour, and spicy Goan fish curry, typically made with red snapper or kingfish, and a ground spice paste.

Name: Anjal Tawa Fry
Description: A popular coastal Karnataka dish where Anjal (Kingfish) slices are marinated in a spicy masala and pan-fried on a tawa.

Name: Awadhi Biryani
Description: A fragrant and flavorful biryani from Lucknow, known for its mild spices, tender meat (chicken/mutton), and aromatic basmati rice cooked in a 'dum' style.

Name: Bangude Pulimunchi
Description: A traditional Mangalorean fish curry made with Bangude (Mackerel), characterized by its tangy (puli) and spicy (munchi) flavors, often with coconut.

Name: Beef Curry
Description: A rich and robust curry made with beef chunks, slow-cooked with a blend of aromatic spices, often varying by regional influences.

Name: Beef Cutlet
Description: Spiced ground beef mixed with potatoes or breadcrumbs, shaped into patties, coated with breadcrumbs, and fried until golden brown.

Name: Beef Ularthiyathu
Description: A quintessential Kerala beef dry roast, slow-cooked with a rich blend of spices, coconut slices, and curry leaves until tender and aromatic.

Name: Bombil Fry (Bombay Duck Fry)
Description: A popular Maharashtrian delicacy where Bombil (Bombay Duck) fish is marinated in spices and fried until crisp.

Name: Butter Chicken
Description: A world-renowned Indian dish with tender chicken pieces cooked in a rich, creamy, and mildly spiced tomato-based gravy, finished with butter and cream.

Name: Chicken Afghani
Description: Chicken marinated in a creamy, mild, and aromatic blend of yogurt, cream, cheese, and spices, then grilled or baked.

Name: Chicken Biryani
Description: A classic Indian one-pot dish of tender chicken pieces, marinated in spices, layered with fragrant basmati rice, and slow-cooked to perfection.

Name: Chicken Cafreal
Description: A Goan-Portuguese fusion dish, chicken marinated in a vibrant green paste of coriander, green chilies, ginger, and garlic, then pan-fried or curried.

Name: Chicken Chettinad
Description: A robust and aromatic chicken curry from the Chettinad region of Tamil Nadu, known for its unique blend of freshly ground spices including star anise, fennel, and black stone flower.

Name: Chicken Chilli
Description: A popular Indo-Chinese dish with crispy fried chicken pieces tossed in a spicy and tangy sauce with bell peppers, onions, and green chilies.

Name: Chicken Crispy Noodles
Description: Crispy fried noodles topped with a savory and spicy gravy containing chicken pieces and mixed vegetables.

Name: Chicken Handi
Description: A rich and aromatic chicken curry cooked in a traditional clay pot (handi), often with yogurt, cream, and a blend of spices.

Name: Chicken Hariyali Tikka
Description: Boneless chicken pieces marinated in a vibrant green paste of mint, coriander, and other spices, then grilled or baked.

Name: Chicken Hyderabadi
Description: A rich and spicy chicken dish from Hyderabad, often characterized by its use of green chilies, mint, coriander, and yogurt.

Name: Chicken Kebab
Description: Skewered and grilled pieces of marinated chicken, often served as an appetizer.

Name: Chicken Kolhapuri
Description: A fiery and aromatic chicken curry from Kolhapur, Maharashtra, known for its bold spices including red chilies and coconut.

Name: Chicken Kurma
Description: A rich and creamy chicken curry, typically milder than other curries, made with yogurt, nuts (like cashews and almonds), and subtle spices.

Name: Chicken Lahori
Description: A flavorful and spicy chicken curry originating from Lahore, known for its deep flavors from slow cooking with a blend of spices.

Name: Chicken Malai Tikka
Description: Creamy, melt-in-your-mouth boneless chicken pieces marinated in yogurt, cream, cheese, and mild spices, then grilled.

Name: Chicken Masala
Description: A general term for chicken cooked in a spiced gravy, widely popular across India with regional variations.

Name: Chicken Mughlai
Description: A rich, creamy, and mildly spiced chicken curry inspired by Mughal cuisine, featuring nuts, cream, and aromatic spices.

Name: Chicken Schezwan Noodles
Description: Stir-fried noodles with chicken and vegetables tossed in a spicy and tangy Schezwan sauce.

Name: Chicken Stew
Description: A wholesome and mildly spiced chicken stew, often made with coconut milk and vegetables, popular in South India.

Name: Chicken Tikka
Description: Marinated boneless chicken pieces, typically roasted in a tandoor, known for its smoky flavor and tender texture.

Name: Chicken Tikka Biryani
Description: A flavorful biryani prepared with aromatic basmati rice and succulent pieces of tandoor-cooked chicken tikka.

Name: Chicken Tikka Masala
Description: Marinated and grilled chicken pieces (tikka) simmered in a creamy, spiced tomato-based sauce.

Name: Chingri Malai Curry
Description: A traditional Bengali prawn curry cooked in a rich, creamy coconut milk gravy with mild spices.

Name: Chingri Macher Malaikari
Description: Bengali style Prawn Malaikari, a classic dish where prawns are cooked in a creamy coconut milk gravy.

Name: Crab Curry
Description: Crab cooked in a spiced gravy, with various regional interpretations from tangy to spicy, often with coconut.

Name: Crab Masala
Description: Dryer preparation of crab with rich spices, usually cooked until the gravy is thick and clings to the crab meat.

Name: Crab Roast
Description: Crab pieces roasted with a medley of spices, often with a semi-dry consistency and intense flavor.

Name: Crab Sukka
Description: A popular Mangalorean dry preparation of crab, cooked with roasted spices and often grated coconut.

Name: Dal Baati Churma
Description: A traditional Rajasthani dish consisting of baked wheat balls (baati), served with mixed lentils (dal) and a sweet crumbled wheat dessert (churma).

Name: Dhansak
Description: A Parsi dish, typically made with mutton or chicken, slow-cooked with lentils and vegetables, served with brown rice.

Name: Donne Biryani
Description: A distinctive biryani from Bangalore, traditionally served in a cup made of palm leaves (donne), often made with short-grain rice and a unique spice blend.

Name: Doi Maach
Description: A classic Bengali fish curry prepared with yogurt (doi) and mustard oil, giving it a tangy and rich flavor.

Name: Duck Mappas
Description: A traditional Kerala-style duck curry cooked in a rich and fragrant coconut milk gravy with mild spices.

Name: Duck Roast
Description: Duck pieces roasted with a spicy mix of traditional Kerala spices, resulting in a rich, semi-dry preparation.

Name: Egg Biryani
Description: A flavorful biryani prepared with aromatic basmati rice and boiled eggs, spiced with traditional biryani masala.

Name: Egg Roast
Description: Boiled eggs cooked in a spicy, semi-dry gravy, a popular side dish or main course, especially in Kerala.

Name: Fish Caldine
Description: A mild and creamy Goan fish curry made with coconut milk and delicate spices, known for its light texture.

Name: Fish Moilee
Description: A famous Kerala-style fish curry, mild and creamy, made with coconut milk, green chilies, and ginger-garlic.

Name: Fish Roe Curry (Mangalorean)
Description: A unique Mangalorean curry featuring fish roe cooked in a spicy and tangy coconut-based gravy.

Name: Galouti Kebab
Description: Melt-in-your-mouth minced meat kebabs, famously from Lucknow, known for their ultra-soft texture.

Name: Goan Fish Curry
Description: A tangy and spicy fish curry from Goa, often made with kokum or tamarind, and coconut, giving it a distinctive sour flavor.

Name: Goan Prawn Curry
Description: A spicy and tangy prawn curry from Goa, with a prominent taste of coconut and often kokum or tamarind.

Name: Gosht Nihari
Description: A slow-cooked, rich and flavorful stew made with tender meat (lamb/goat) and various spices, often garnished with ginger and green chilies.

Name: Gushtaba
Description: A Kashmiri delicacy consisting of minced mutton meatballs cooked in a rich, creamy yogurt-based gravy.

Name: Hyderabadi Biryani
Description: A world-renowned biryani from Hyderabad, made with basmati rice, meat (usually chicken or mutton), and a blend of aromatic spices, slow-cooked to perfection.

Name: Jungli Maas
Description: A rustic Rajasthani mutton dish, traditionally cooked with minimal ingredients like mutton, ghee, and dried red chilies.

Name: Kakka Irachi Ularthiyathu
Description: A popular Kerala-style dry stir-fry of clams, cooked with coconut pieces and a spicy blend of regional spices.

Name: Kalmi Kabab
Description: Chicken drumsticks marinated in yogurt, cream, and spices, then roasted or grilled to perfection.

Name: Kane Fry
Description: A popular Mangalorean preparation of Lady Fish (Kane), marinated in a spicy masala and pan-fried until crispy.

Name: Karimeen Pollichathu
Description: A Kerala delicacy where Pearl Spot fish (Karimeen) is marinated, wrapped in banana leaves, and pan-fried or baked.

Name: Kerala Fish Moilee
Description: A mild, creamy, and subtly spiced fish curry from Kerala, made with fresh coconut milk.

Name: Kingfish Fry
Description: Kingfish slices marinated in a spicy masala and pan-fried or deep-fried until golden and crispy.

Name: Kodi Pulao
Description: A flavorful chicken pulao where chicken is cooked with rice and aromatic spices, a simpler version of biryani.

Name: Kolhapuri Chicken Sukha
Description: A spicy and dry chicken preparation from Kolhapur, characterized by its intense flavor and use of dry roasted spices and coconut.

Name: Kolhapuri Mutton Sukha
Description: A very spicy and dry mutton preparation from Kolhapur, known for its strong flavors from special Kolhapuri masalas.

Name: Koli Barthad
Description: A traditional Coorgi chicken dry fry, spicy and tangy with the distinct flavor of 'kachampuli' (Coorg vinegar).

Name: Koli Curry (Coorgi Style)
Description: A distinctive chicken curry from Coorg, known for its unique blend of spices and often the tanginess of 'kachampuli' (Coorg vinegar).

Name: Koli Gassi
Description: A classic Mangalorean chicken curry, rich and spicy, with a thick gravy made from roasted spices and coconut.

Name: Koli Sukka
Description: A dry, spicy chicken dish from the Mangalorean region, made with roasted spices and grated coconut, typically served as a side.

Name: Koonthal Roast
Description: Spicy and flavorful squid (koonthal) roasted with traditional Kerala spices, often with a semi-dry consistency.

Name: Korma (Mughlai)
Description: A rich, creamy, and mildly spiced curry, typically made with meat (chicken, mutton) or vegetables, using yogurt, cream, and nuts.

Name: Kosha Mangsho
Description: A traditional Bengali mutton curry, slow-cooked in a spicy, thick, and rich gravy until the meat is tender and coated.

Name: Laal Maas
Description: A famous Rajasthani mutton curry, intensely spicy and vibrant red, cooked with mathania chilies and yogurt.

Name: Machher Jhol
Description: A traditional Bengali fish curry characterized by its light, soupy, and spicy gravy with a hint of mustard.

Name: Malabar Chicken Biryani
Description: A unique biryani from the Malabar region of Kerala, made with short-grain rice (Kaima/Jeerakasala) and tender chicken, distinct for its mild spice and layered flavors.

Name: Malabar Fish Curry
Description: A spicy and tangy fish curry from the Malabar coast, often with a base of coconut milk and a hint of kokum or raw mango for sourness.

Name: Mutton Biryani
Description: Aromatic basmati rice layered with tender mutton pieces, cooked with a medley of spices and herbs.

Name: Mutton Curry (Coorgi Style)
Description: A spicy and tangy mutton curry from Coorg, known for its distinct use of local spices and 'kachampuli' (Coorg vinegar).

Name: Mutton Handi
Description: Tender mutton pieces slow-cooked in a traditional clay pot (handi) with a rich and aromatic gravy.

Name: Mutton Hyderabadi
Description: A spicy and aromatic mutton dish from Hyderabad, often with a rich gravy and distinct flavors from fresh herbs.

Name: Mutton Kadai
Description: Mutton pieces cooked in a heavy-bottomed wok (kadai) with bell peppers, onions, tomatoes, and a robust spice blend.

Name: Mutton Kolhapuri
Description: A fiery Maharashtrian mutton curry from Kolhapur, known for its bold and pungent spices, often with coconut.

Name: Mutton Masala
Description: A general term for mutton cooked in a rich, spiced gravy, a staple across many Indian cuisines.

Name: Mutton Mughlai
Description: A rich, creamy, and mildly spiced mutton curry from Mughal cuisine, often with nuts, cream, and aromatic spices.

Name: Mutton Kundapura Curry
Description: A robust and spicy mutton curry from the Kundapura region of Karnataka, known for its blend of roasted spices and coconut.

Name: Mutton Stew
Description: A wholesome and mildly spiced mutton stew, often made with coconut milk and vegetables, popular in South India.

Name: Mutton Varattiyathu
Description: A spicy and dry roasted mutton dish from Kerala, slow-cooked until the meat is tender and coated with aromatic spices.

Name: Mysore Mutton Chops
Description: Spicy and flavorful mutton chops, typically pan-fried or roasted with a unique blend of Mysore spices.

Name: Nadan Beef Fry
Description: A classic Kerala-style beef fry, slow-cooked until tender and then roasted with aromatic spices and coconut slices.

Name: Nadan Kozhi Curry
Description: Authentic Kerala-style chicken curry, often made with coconut milk and traditional spices, giving it a rich and robust flavor.

Name: Nargisi Kofta
Description: A Mughlai dish featuring boiled eggs encased in minced meat (kofta), served in a rich and flavorful gravy.

Name: Octopus Fry
Description: Marinated octopus pieces pan-fried or deep-fried with a spicy and tangy masala.

Name: Pabda Macher Jhol
Description: A Bengali fish curry made with Pabda fish (Indian butterfish), cooked in a light, spicy, and flavorful gravy.

Name: Pandi Curry
Description: A signature Coorgi pork curry, known for its rich, dark color and tangy flavor from 'kachampuli' (Coorg vinegar).

Name: Pandi Fry
Description: A spicy and dry preparation of pork, popular in Coorg, seasoned with traditional spices.

Name: Pasanda (Lamb)
Description: A rich and creamy Mughlai curry made with thin strips of tender lamb, often cooked with cream, yogurt, and nuts.

Name: Pork Vindaloo
Description: A fiery and tangy Goan pork curry, marinated in vinegar and a blend of intense spices, traditionally cooked for a long time.

Name: Prawn Malai Curry
Description: A rich and creamy Bengali prawn curry, typically made with coconut milk and delicate spices.

Name: Prawn Roast
Description: Prawns roasted with a spicy masala until semi-dry, a flavorful side or appetizer.

Name: Prawn Sukka
Description: A popular Mangalorean dry preparation of prawns, cooked with roasted spices and often grated coconut.

Name: Prawns Biryani Seasonal
Description: A seasonal biryani featuring prawns cooked with aromatic basmati rice and a blend of biryani spices.

Name: Prawns Koliwada
Description: Crispy, deep-fried prawns coated in a spicy red batter, a popular street food and appetizer.

Name: Recheado Masala Fish Fry
Description: Fish coated with a fiery Goan Recheado masala (a paste of red chilies, vinegar, and spices) and pan-fried.

Name: Recheado Masala
Description: A spicy and tangy Goan paste made from red chilies, vinegar, and various spices, used for marinating fish or meat.

Name: Rista
Description: A Kashmiri delicacy, Rista consists of soft and velvety meatballs made from pounded mutton, cooked in a rich red gravy.

Name: Rogan Josh
Description: A classic Kashmiri lamb or mutton curry, characterized by its vibrant red color from dried Kashmiri chilies and rich, aromatic gravy.

Name: Saag Gosht
Description: A hearty dish combining meat (usually mutton or lamb) with spinach and other greens, cooked in a flavorful spiced gravy.

Name: Safed Maas
Description: A white mutton curry from Rajasthan, mildly spiced and creamy, made with yogurt, cream, and nuts, without red chilies.

Name: Sardine Curry
Description: A flavorful and often spicy curry made with sardines, popular in coastal regions of India.

Name: Shevgyachya Shenga Amti
Description: A Maharashtrian drumstick curry or stew, tangy and spicy, typically made with lentils and coconut.

Name: Shorshe Ilish
Description: A iconic Bengali dish where Hilsa fish (Ilish) is cooked in a pungent mustard-based gravy.

Name: Squid Roast
Description: Spicy and flavorful squid roasted with traditional South Indian spices, often with a semi-dry consistency.

Name: Surmai Fry
Description: King Mackerel (Surmai) slices marinated in a spicy masala and pan-fried or shallow-fried until cooked through.

Name: Tahari
Description: A flavorful and aromatic rice dish, similar to pulao, often made with vegetables or sometimes meat, characterized by its yellow color from turmeric.

Name: Tandoor Chicken
Description: Chicken marinated in yogurt and spices, then roasted in a tandoor (clay oven), giving it a smoky flavor and charred exterior.

Name: Yakhni
Description: A clear, aromatic broth, often made with meat (lamb/mutton) and delicate spices, popular in Kashmiri cuisine.

Name: Yerechi Curry
Description: A traditional Coorgi meat curry, typically made with lamb or mutton, known for its rich spice blend and robust flavor.

Name: Akini Chokibo
Description: A traditional Nagaland dish made from fermented soybeans and pork, known for its distinct pungent flavor.

Name: Chakhwi
Description: A traditional Tripura stew, often made with chicken or pork, bamboo shoots, and a local spice blend.

Name: Doh Khlieh
Description: A traditional Khasi salad from Meghalaya made with boiled pork pieces, onions, ginger, and green chilies.

Name: Gongura Mamsam
Description: A spicy and tangy mutton curry from Andhra Pradesh, featuring the distinctive sourness of Gongura leaves (sorrel leaves).

Name: Gongura Kodi
Description: A spicy and tangy chicken curry from Andhra Pradesh, made with the sour Gongura leaves (sorrel leaves).

Name: Jadoh
Description: A traditional Khasi rice dish from Meghalaya, cooked with meat (often pork or chicken) and minimal spices, giving it a unique flavor.

Name: Kangshoi (Chamthong)
Description: A light and healthy Manipuri vegetable stew, flavored with fermented fish (Ngari) and various herbs.

Name: Kankada Jhola
Description: An Odia (Oriya) crab curry, cooked in a spicy and flavorful gravy.

Name: Kothu Kari
Description: Minced mutton or lamb cooked in a spicy masala, often with peas, a popular South Indian dish.

Name: Luker
Description: A spicy dry pork dish from Nagaland, often made with smoked pork and local herbs.

Name: Misa Mach Poora
Description: A Mizo delicacy consisting of grilled prawns, often marinated in local spices and herbs.

Name: Mui Borok
Description: A traditional Tripuri dry fish chutney, a pungent and spicy condiment made with fermented fish (berma).

Name: Nakham Bitchi
Description: A traditional Garo soup made with a special type of dried fish, vegetables, and rice flour, known for its unique flavor.

Name: Pika Pila
Description: A pungent and spicy pickle from Arunachal Pradesh, often made with meat (like pork), bamboo shoots, and Bhoot Jolokia chili.

Name: Pork with Raja Mircha (Bhoot Jolokia)
Description: A hyper-spicy Naga dish where pork is cooked with the world-renowned Bhoot Jolokia (ghost pepper), a true fiery experience.

Name: Smoked Pork with Bamboo Shoot
Description: A flavorful and aromatic dish popular in Northeast India, featuring tender smoked pork cooked with bamboo shoots and local spices.

Name: Thambou Singju
Description: A refreshing Manipuri salad made with lotus stem (thambou), other vegetables, and herbs, often with a hint of fermented fish paste.

Name: Vawksa Rep
Description: A traditional Mizo dish featuring smoked pork, often cooked with bamboo shoots and local spices, yielding a savory and smoky flavor.

Name: Virudhunagar Parotta Salna
Description: A combination of soft, layered South Indian flatbread (Parotta) served with a thin, spicy, and aromatic gravy (Salna), popular in Virudhunagar.

Name: Yeti Gassi
Description: A classic Mangalorean prawn curry (Yeti/Etti means prawn), rich and spicy, with a thick gravy made from roasted spices and coconut.

Name: Yeti Sukka
Description: A popular Mangalorean dry preparation of prawns (Yeti/Etti), cooked with roasted spices and grated coconut.

Name: Meen Pollichathu
Description: A Kerala specialty where fish (often Pearl Spot) is marinated, coated with a spicy masala, wrapped in banana leaves, and cooked.

Name: Mustard Fish
Description: Fish cooked in a pungent and flavorful mustard-based gravy, popular in Bengali cuisine.

Name: Mustard Chicken
Description: Chicken cooked in a pungent and flavorful mustard-based gravy, a popular Bengali preparation.

Name: Chicken Xacuti
Description: A rich and spicy Goan chicken curry with roasted spices, grated coconut, and poppy seeds, giving it a unique flavor profile.

Name: Pondicherry Fish Curry
Description: A tangy and spicy fish curry from the Pondicherry region, often with a distinct flavor from local spices and tamarind.

Name: Khowsuey
Description: A Burmese noodle soup served with various toppings, typically with coconut milk, often made vegetarian or with chicken.

Name: Mutton Stew
Description: A mild, creamy stew with tender mutton pieces cooked in coconut milk and spices, popular in Kerala and other parts of South India.

Name: Poriyal
Description: A South Indian dry stir-fry dish made with finely chopped vegetables, grated coconut, and spices. It is served as a side dish with rice.

Name: Thorans
Description: A dry vegetable curry from Kerala, often made with shredded vegetables, lentils, or greens, and sautéed with coconut and spices.

Name: Kori Ajadina
Description: A spicy and flavorful dry chicken dish from the Mangalorean Tuluva community. 'Kori' means chicken and 'Ajadina' means dry in Tulu language.

Name: Malabar Parotta with Beef Fry
Description: A popular dish from Kerala featuring flaky, layered Malabar Parotta served with a spicy, dry beef fry.

Name: Malabar Parotta with Beef Curry
Description: A classic combination of flaky, soft Malabar Parotta served with a rich, aromatic beef curry from Kerala.

Name: Thali Meals
Description: A complete Indian meal served on a single platter, comprising various dishes like rice, roti, dal, curries, vegetables, and dessert.

Name: Kothu Parotta
Description: A popular South Indian street food dish made with shredded Malabar Parotta stir-fried with vegetables, eggs, or meat, and spices.

Name: Akki Rotti
Description: A traditional Karnataka breakfast dish, a flatbread made from rice flour and various vegetables and spices.

Name: Ammesala Dosa
Description: A variety of Dosa from Karnataka, made with a fermented batter of rice and lentils, typically served for breakfast.

Name: Appam
Description: A lacy, bowl-shaped pancake from Kerala and Tamil Nadu, made with a fermented rice batter and coconut milk. It is soft and thick in the center and thin at the edges.

Name: Bhatura
Description: A fluffy, deep-fried leavened bread, often served with Chole (chickpea curry) to make the popular dish 'Chole Bhature'.

Name: Bisi Bele Bath
Description: A spicy, hot, and flavorful one-pot rice dish from Karnataka, made with rice, lentils, vegetables, and a special spice blend.

Name: Chapati
Description: A staple Indian flatbread made from whole wheat flour, a simple, unleavened bread cooked on a hot griddle.

Name: Chitranna
Description: A flavorful and tangy lemon rice dish from Karnataka, tempered with mustard seeds, peanuts, and curry leaves.

Name: Chiratta Puttu
Description: A variant of Puttu, a steamed rice cake from Kerala, where the mixture is steamed inside a coconut shell mold ('chiratta').

Name: Curd Rice (Thayir Sadam)
Description: A comforting South Indian dish made by mixing rice with yogurt, tempered with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and green chilies.

Name: Donne Biryani
Description: A fragrant and spicy Biryani from Bengaluru, cooked with short-grain rice and a unique green masala, traditionally served in a palm leaf bowl ('donne').

Name: Dosa
Description: A thin, crispy, savory crepe made from a fermented batter of rice and lentils, a popular breakfast and snack from South India.

Name: Godhi Dosa
Description: A dosa variety made with wheat flour ('godhi' in Kannada) instead of the traditional rice and lentil batter. It is a quick and healthy option.

Name: Godhi Rotti
Description: A flatbread made from wheat flour ('godhi' in Kannada), a simple and unleavened bread cooked on a griddle, similar to Chapati.

Name: Huli Anna
Description: A tangy and spicy rice dish from Karnataka, flavored with a tamarind-based curry ('huli' means sour/tangy) and spices.

Name: Idli
Description: A soft, fluffy, steamed savory cake made from a fermented batter of rice and lentils, a very popular breakfast item in South India.

Name: Idiyappam
Description: Also known as string hoppers, these are a Kerala specialty of delicate, steamed rice flour noodles, served with curries or coconut milk.

Name: Jolada Dosa
Description: A flatbread or dosa made from jowar (sorghum) flour, a traditional and healthy food from North Karnataka.

Name: Jolada Rotti
Description: A staple unleavened flatbread from North Karnataka, made from jowar (sorghum) flour. It's known for its rustic flavor and health benefits.

Name: Kappa Puttu
Description: A variation of Puttu, where tapioca ('kappa') is added to the rice flour mixture, resulting in a different texture and flavor.

Name: Khali Idli
Description: A type of soft, fluffy Idli from Bengaluru, often served in a set of two or three with a mild chutney and Sagu (vegetable curry).

Name: Khameeri Roti
Description: A soft, fluffy, fermented flatbread from Mughlai cuisine, with a slightly tangy flavor. It is traditionally cooked in a tandoor.

Name: Kotte Kadubu
Description: A steamed rice cake from Karnataka, similar to Idli, but cooked inside a mold made from Jackfruit or Teak leaves, which imparts a unique aroma.

Name: Lachha Paratha
Description: A popular layered flatbread from North India, known for its flaky, crispy texture. It is made by folding and rolling the dough multiple times.

Name: Lemon Rice
Description: A quick and easy South Indian rice dish, seasoned with mustard seeds, peanuts, curry leaves, and a generous squeeze of lemon juice.

Name: Litti Chokha
Description: A traditional dish from Bihar and Jharkhand. 'Litti' are roasted wheat balls filled with sattu (roasted gram flour) and spices, served with 'Chokha', a spicy mashed vegetable mix.

Name: Makki Di Roti
Description: A traditional Punjabi flatbread made from maize flour ('makki'). It is often served with 'Sarson da Saag' (mustard greens curry) and a dollop of butter or ghee.

Name: Malabar Parotta
Description: A soft, flaky, and layered flatbread from Kerala, made from maida (all-purpose flour). It's a popular accompaniment to curries.

Name: Matta Rice
Description: A red parboiled rice from Kerala, known for its earthy flavor and nutritional value. It is often served with curries and vegetables.

Name: Missi Roti
Description: A flatbread from North India made with a mix of wheat and gram flour, flavored with spices like fenugreek and cumin.

Name: Momo
Description: A popular steamed dumpling from Tibet and Nepal, filled with a savory mixture of minced meat or vegetables, served with a spicy dipping sauce.

Name: Mosaru Anna
Description: A comforting South Indian dish, the Kannada version of Curd Rice, made by mixing rice with yogurt and a simple tempering of spices.

Name: Navane Dosa
Description: A healthy dosa variety made from Foxtail Millet flour ('Navane' in Kannada), a gluten-free and nutritious alternative to traditional dosa.

Name: Neer Dosa
Description: A soft, delicate, and thin crepe from the Tulu Nadu region, made with a simple rice batter. 'Neer' means water in Tulu, referring to its watery consistency.

Name: Nool Puttu
Description: Also known as Idiyappam, these are delicate, steamed rice flour noodles, a Kerala specialty, often served with curries or coconut milk.

Name: Nool Puttu with Pandi Curry
Description: A traditional Coorg dish pairing delicate Nool Puttu (steamed rice noodles) with a spicy and tangy Pork ('Pandi') curry.

Name: Ottu Shavige
Description: A steamed dish of fine rice vermicelli or noodles, a Karnataka specialty that is often served with a variety of sweet or savory accompaniments.

Name: Paneer Biryani
Description: A fragrant and flavorful vegetarian biryani, made with basmati rice, marinated paneer (Indian cottage cheese), and aromatic spices.

Name: Papad
Description: A thin, crispy wafer made from lentil or chickpea flour, seasoned with spices. It can be roasted or deep-fried and is served as a side dish or snack.

Name: Poha
Description: A popular breakfast or snack from Central and Western India, made from flattened rice, sautéed with vegetables, peanuts, and spices.

Name: Plain Dosa
Description: A thin, crispy, savory crepe made from a fermented batter of rice and lentils, a popular breakfast and snack from South India.

Name: Porotta
Description: Another name for Malabar Parotta, a soft, flaky, and layered flatbread from Kerala, made from maida (all-purpose flour).

Name: Pulihora
Description: A tangy and spicy tamarind rice dish from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, tempered with mustard seeds, lentils, and peanuts.

Name: Puri
Description: A light, fluffy, deep-fried flatbread made from wheat flour, a popular North Indian breakfast or snack.

Name: Puttu
Description: A steamed rice cake from Kerala, made in a cylindrical shape with layers of ground rice flour and grated coconut.

Name: Ragi Dosa
Description: A healthy dosa variety made from finger millet ('Ragi' in Kannada) flour, known for its nutritional benefits and rustic flavor.

Name: Ragi Mudde
Description: A staple diet of rural Karnataka, a nutritious ball made from finger millet ('Ragi') flour and hot water. It's eaten by hand with curry.

Name: Ragi Rotti
Description: A healthy flatbread from Karnataka, made from finger millet ('Ragi') flour and vegetables, a popular and nutritious breakfast item.

Name: Rajma Chawal
Description: A popular North Indian dish of kidney bean curry ('rajma') served with steamed rice ('chawal'). It is a comforting and nutritious meal.

Name: Rawa Idli
Description: A quick and instant variety of Idli, made from semolina ('rawa') instead of the traditional rice and lentil batter. It is soft and savory.

Name: Red Rice
Description: A type of unpolished rice with a reddish husk, known for its high fiber content and nutty flavor. It's a healthy alternative to white rice.

Name: Roti
Description: A staple Indian flatbread made from whole wheat flour, a simple, unleavened bread cooked on a hot griddle. Another name for Chapati.

Name: Sajje Rotti
Description: A flatbread from North Karnataka made from pearl millet ('Sajje' in Kannada) flour, a healthy and gluten-free alternative to wheat-based rotis.

Name: Sajjige Dosa
Description: A dosa variety made from semolina ('sajjige' in Kannada), a quick and easy-to-make dosa that is slightly thicker than traditional ones.

Name: Set Dosa
Description: A set of soft, spongy, and thick dosas, a specialty from Karnataka, served in a stack with a mild vegetable curry (sagu) and chutney.

Name: Shavige Uppittu
Description: A popular South Indian breakfast dish made from steamed rice vermicelli, tempered with mustard seeds, curry leaves, and vegetables.

Name: Tahari
Description: A flavorful and aromatic rice dish from North India, a vegetarian version of biryani, cooked with rice, vegetables, and spices.

Name: Tamarind Rice (Puliyodarai)
Description: A tangy and spicy tamarind rice dish from South India, tempered with mustard seeds, lentils, and peanuts.

Name: Thali Peet
Description: A savory, multi-grain flatbread from Maharashtra, made with a mix of flours like jowar, bajra, and rice, and spiced with vegetables and herbs.

Name: Thupad Akki Rotti
Description: A variety of Akki Rotti from Karnataka, made with rice flour and vegetables, often cooked with a generous amount of ghee ('Thupad').

Name: Uppittu
Description: A popular South Indian breakfast dish made from roasted semolina ('rawa' or 'sooji'), tempered with spices and vegetables. Also known as Upma.

Name: Uttapam
Description: A thick, savory pancake from South India, made with a fermented rice and lentil batter and topped with various vegetables.

Name: Vangi Bath
Description: A spicy and flavorful rice dish from Karnataka, made with rice and brinjal (eggplant) and a special spice powder.

Name: Veg Noodles
Description: A popular Indo-Chinese dish of stir-fried noodles with a variety of vegetables and sauces.

Name: Veg Pulav
Description: A fragrant and flavorful rice dish cooked with basmati rice, mixed vegetables, and aromatic spices.

Name: Vegetable Pulao
Description: A fragrant and flavorful rice dish cooked with basmati rice, mixed vegetables, and aromatic spices.

Name: Vellayappam
Description: A soft, spongy, and fluffy pancake from Kerala, similar to Appam but cooked on a flat griddle. It is made from a fermented rice and coconut batter.

Name: White Rice
Description: Staple steamed white rice, a common accompaniment to curries and other dishes in many cuisines.

Name: Wheat Flour Dosa
Description: A quick and easy dosa made from wheat flour, a healthy and instant alternative to the traditional fermented rice and lentil dosa.

Name: Pulihora
Description: A tangy and spicy tamarind rice dish from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, tempered with mustard seeds, lentils, and peanuts.

Name: Jonna Roti
Description: A flatbread made from jowar (sorghum) flour, a staple of North Karnataka and parts of Maharashtra, known for being gluten-free and healthy.

Name: Thukpa
Description: A hearty and nutritious noodle soup with vegetables and/or meat, originating from Tibet and popular in the Himalayan regions of India.

Name: Sattu Paratha
Description: A North Indian flatbread stuffed with a spicy mixture of sattu (roasted gram flour) and spices. It is a hearty and filling breakfast.

Name: Muglai Paratha
